Question: What is the difference between the two types of prion diseases?
Answer: Prion diseases are a group of rare, fatal neurodegenerative disorders that are caused by misfolding of the prion protein (PrP). There are two main types of prion diseases: sporadic and inherited.
Sporadic prion diseases are the most common type of prion disease and occur when the PrP protein is misfolded in the brain. This misfolding can occur spontaneously (sporadically) or be inherited from a parent. The most well-known sporadic prion disease is Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), which is a rapidly progressive, fatal disease that affects the brain.
Inherited prion diseases are caused by mutations in the PrP gene that lead to the production of abnormal PrP proteins. These mutations can be inherited from a parent or occur spontaneously. The most common inherited prion disease is familial Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (fCJD), which is a slowly progressive, fatal disease that affects the brain.
It is important to note that prion diseases can also be caused by exposure to contaminated food or tissues (iatrogenic) or by exposure to the prions of other animals (zoonotic).
